title: Energy Balance and Macronutrients in Weight Loss
content: Energy balance is about tracking calories in and calories out, which is the energy consumed and energy spent. A calorie is a unit of measurement for energy stored in the chemical bonds of food. When food is broken down, these molecules go through metabolism and energy is liberated. Energy is stored in fat in adipose tissue, which is a store of excess energy. Some energy can also be stored in glycogen. The contribution of glycogen to your relative energy stores is actually really small, about 1500 to 2000 calories of energy. So your adipose tissue is by far the biggest energy store.

title: Importance of Protein in Weightlifting
content: Protein plays a crucial role in weightlifting. Two case studies were discussed. The first case was a 50-year old female who wants to improve her health through nutrition and exercise. She was more interested in cardio than lifting weights. The second case was a 40-50-year old male who wants to focus on maximizing muscle mass. These 2 cases are illustrative of what many people are going through.

title: Supplements in Bodybuilding
content: A number of supplements were discussed, including whey protein, branch chain amino acids, leucine specifically as one of the branch chain amino acids, creatine, and nitric oxide boosters.

title: Factors Influencing Total Daily Energy Expenditure
content: Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is usually about 50-70% of the energy people expend per day. This is basically the cost of keeping the lights on. BMR can be measured by putting someone in a metabolic chamber and having them lie there awake but not moving. This is slightly different from the energy expenditure while sleeping (the resting metabolic rate, RMR). Factors influencing energy expenditure include lean mass, which requires quite a bit of oxygen compared to adipose tissue. Also when you start doing activity, it requires a lot of oxygen. All the energy you expend in 1 day is called the TDEE (total daily energy expenditure). The biggest portion of this for most people is the BMR.

title: Non-Exercise Activity Thermogenesis (NEAT)
content: For most people, the biggest component of their physical activity is something called NEAT (non-exercise activity thermogenesis). This is extremely modifiable. People who are resistant to obesity tend to fidget a lot. Obese-prone individuals tend to have a very low NEAT. NEAT seems like nothing, a fidget, but thousands of those movements over the course of a day actually add up. It appears to be modifiable by about 500 – 600 calories per day. This is seen in both overfeeding and underfeeding studies. People who lose 10% of their body weight, they’ve seen up to a 500 calorie reduction in NEAT.

title: Tracking Energy Expenditure and Calorie Intake
content: The challenge of tracking energy expenditure accurately, and the thermic effect of different macronutrients. Wrist devices that measure energy expenditures are not particularly accurate. A study of wrist devices found they overestimate exercise energy expenditure from 28-93%. It is also difficult to accurately track calories because there is up to a 20% error allowed in food labels. People also have trouble estimating their energy intake. There was a study in the 90s of people who self-reported as resistant to weight loss. They had the people track and report their food and found the average under reporting was 50%.

title: Experiment Tracking Energy Expenditure
content: 8 years ago Peter had the luxury of being able to spend 6 days inside a metabolic chamber, in 2-day blocks. Afterwards he did a 10-day doubly labeled water (DLW) experience. The only instruction to Peter when doing this was try to keep his weight stable for that period of time, which he was able to do. By his calculations he was taking in 4,400 calories (this would imply an expenditure of 4,400 calories). The DLW (doubly labeled water) showed an expenditure of 4,200 calories.

title: Thermic Effect of Different Macronutrients
content: Consider the TEF (thermic effect of food) of various foods. The TEF is the amount of energy your body has to put in to extract chemical energy out of food. Fat has the lowest TEF; it’s between 0-3 calories per 100 calories of fat. Carbohydrates have a TEF of 5-10%. Protein has a TEF of 20-30%.

title: Challenges of Sustained Weight Loss
content: One challenge of sustainable weight loss over a long period of time is how much is enough on a daily basis before an adaptation takes place that would correct it. If you went on a 500 calorie deficit per day (a pretty significant deficit), do you lose linearly 1 lb per week until you no longer exist and you die because there’s no more body weight? No, we all know that weight loss plateaus. Part of this is because you have less body mass. There is also the NEAT component. As you lose weight, you become spontaneously less active.

title: Weight Loss Strategies
content: Tracking calories is like keeping a budget. Energy expenditure depends on a lot of variables and is likely to change. This has led people to think that we can’t accurately track calories in or out so there’s no point in tracking calories. But this is like saying, “Keeping a budget is worthless, because I have multiple streams of revenue and I have investments. And so I can’t exactly how much income I’m getting. And also things pop up, like your car breaks down, you have repairs to your house. So you can’t exactly know what your expenses are going to be. So therefore keeping a budget is worthless.”

title: Commonalities in people who maintain long-term weight-loss
content: The factors that contribute to long-term weight loss are not solely dietary. They include changes in environment, habits, and behavior. Support, either good or bad, plays a significant role. Stress, trauma, and binge eating are also significant factors. Sustainable weight loss is more about reprogramming habits and behaviors than following a particular diet. No one diet was found to be superior. Instead, a series of habits and behaviors that help people lose weight and sustain that weight loss were identified.

title: Does a ketogenic diet result in greater energy expenditure?
content: There is debate about the impact of different macronutrients on energy expenditure. A ketogenic diet results in weight loss through reduction of calories eaten, not an increase in energy expenditure. Difficulties exist in measuring energy expenditure in people eating a ketogenic diet. The carbohydrate insulin model of obesity would predict a much bigger change in energy expenditure. However, studies that assess loss of body fat under controlled environments do not show differences between low carb and low fat when calories and protein are controlled.

title: Refocus on losing body fat
content: When calories and protein are equated, no difference is seen between the low carb conditions, or the low fat, or balanced diet in terms of body fat loss. This suggests that individuals can choose the diet they prefer and still lose body fat. A balanced diet can be harder for some people to moderate unless they are doing some kind of portion control.

title: The metabolic benefits of exercise, muscle mass, and protein intake
content: Having lots of lean body mass is beneficial for metabolic health. Exercise, even without weight loss, substantially improves metabolic health. A high dose of exercise is not required; moving from a sedentary lifestyle to walking 100 minutes a week can result in improvements in health markers. There is a big difference between someone who is an athlete, training hard, with a lot of muscle mass, versus someone who is sedentary with excess adiposity.

title: The impact of lean muscle and strength on lifespan and healthspan
content: Having more muscle mass allows for more flexibility in diet and lifestyle. Older and frail people often overlook the importance of muscle mass. Being in pain and strong is preferable to being in pain and weak. Immobility is detrimental to health. The presence of lean muscle and strength has a positive impact on lifespan and healthspan.

title: Muscle Mass and Aging
content: Muscle is a lot like bone in that you want to lay down as much as possible because eventually, it’s going to start receding. But it is still possible to add muscle. It’s never too late to add muscle. A study on 80-year old frail individuals showed that they increased their lean body mass (as a percentage of their body weight) pretty much the same amount that a 20 year old does. The relative increase was similar. Their weight was lower to start with so they had less overall mass. But by the end, some of them were able to add weight. It’s never too late to get active.

title: Muscle Mass and Mortality
content: There was a review that essentially showed that after age 65, you could tie the majority of deaths to some kind of lack of muscular strength or lack of muscle. Meta analyses of mortality show that lean body mass is inversely proportional to your risk of mortality after age 50. The hazard ratio for being strong to not strong is about 3.2 for all cause mortality.

title: Resistance Training Benefits
content: The benefit gained from spending 30-40 minutes resistance training, 3x a week is unbelievable in terms of your level of fitness and ability to live a long, healthy life. It doesn’t have to be crazy intense training, just an amount that forces your body to adapt.

title: Training Program for Older Individuals
content: Lower body strength is a little bit more important than upper body strength in terms of preventing falls. Bone density is increased by lifting weights much more than anything you’d ever get through your diet. Focus on machine stuff that’s easy to do. Since she has never trained before, everything’s going to cause an adaptation, and that’s the goal.

title: Muscle Protein Synthesis
content: The data on muscle protein turnover doesn’t show increases in hypertrophy during the 1st 6 weeks of resistance training. During this time the tissue is remodeled to become stronger, more resilient, and it starts protecting itself against damage. After about 6 weeks, muscle protein degradation tends to go down while muscle protein synthesis stays up. This is where you start seeing those increases in hypertrophy and lean mass.

title: Protein and Amino Acids Needed for Muscle Mass
content: In order to maximize your deposition to get that 5-10 grams, you need to maximize protein synthesis. But to maximize protein synthesis requires a disproportionate amount of total protein. It’s around 1.6 to 2.4 grams per kilogram of body weight. This kind of winds up with that old 1 gram per pound of body weight number. You need a disproportionate amount of protein to maximize the deposition.

title: Protein Consumption and Metabolism
content: You’ve got to eat a lot more protein to get out what you want; it’s an inefficient system. Some amino acids can be directly oxidized after they are deaminated. Some amino acids can enter the Krebs cycle. 60% of amino acids are glucogenic, fewer are ketogenic. Glucogenic amino acids feed into gluconeogenesis, where the liver uses them to make glucose to supply the body. Ketogenic amino acids can be converted to acetyl-CoA or enter the Krebs cycle at different intermediates and oxidized to produce energy. Branch chain amino acids are the ones that can be oxidized in muscle. These can all feed into the Krebs cycle for oxidation.

title: Nutrition Plan for Building Lean Muscle
content: For the 1st 6 weeks, the goal is don’t get hurt or too sore. Don’t expect to add lean mass. To increase protein, pump up your portion size of lean cuts of meat. You’re not aiming to increase calories but shift the macros more to protein. People can lose fat and gain muscle at the same time. High protein diets actually mimic some of the things that go up during fasting. Adding a protein shake in the morning is not going to mess up benefits of time-restricted eating.

title: Tracking Diet for Muscle Gain
content: If your primary goal is gaining muscle mass, focus on protein, calories, and making sure you have enough carbohydrates. If your primary goal is to maintain body composition, you will put on a little less muscle mass on a low carb diet. This will really boil down to the individual and what you like best. When people get overwhelmed with protein, carbs, and fats he recommends just tracking protein and calories. Most people are getting 99% of the benefits by tracking just calories and protein.

title: Protein Intake and Cancer Risk
content: Many people have heard that mTOR and IGF-1 are bad. mTOR elevations that lead to cancer and whatnot, those originate mostly via insulin resistance. There’s a big difference between a dose of protein that causes mTOR to rise and go back down in a natural rhythm [and a chronic stimulus]. This is also tissue-specific; we’re talking about in skeletal muscle, not liver, not brain necessarily, those sorts of things. The same is true for IGF-1. If we look at the meta-analyses on cancer incidence amongst resistance trainers, we see lower levels of cancer in people who resistance train.

title: Dietary Habits and Lifestyles
content: Poor dietary habits and lifestyles are often tied together. There is a common idea that there is a perfect diet that will reduce cancer, cardiovascular disease, and mortality. However, there are probably trade-offs for everything. High protein diets have been linked to cancer, but there are many cofounders to this. Meta-analysis looking at cancer and protein content of the diet look at above 70 g protein per day (1.2 g / kg body weight). Most Americans eat high protein according to the RDA definition but this is often from burgers, hot dogs, and processed meat. The incidence of cancer in people who have a high protein, but overall healthy diet, is not significantly different. The quality of the overall diet is what is important. Good diet quality can be achieved on a whole host of different diets. It is important to make balanced food choices, ensuring enough fruits, vegetables, minerals, and micronutrients are included.

title: mTOR and Cancer
content: mTOR plays a role in health, but it can’t be the cart before the horse sort of thing. Rapamycin is an mTOR inhibitor and a cancer treatment drug. However, it is not a good idea to use chemotherapy to prevent cancer. Rapamycin has never been a particularly successful cancer therapeutic used consistently. It does show benefits for longevity in basically all animal models. The extrapolation would be pulsatile rapamycin is probably beneficial. But in that application, it’s not really being taken to constantly suppress mTOR. If you took it all the time, you’re suppressing mTOR complex 2 and mTOR complex 1.

title: Training Program for Muscle Mass
content: A 40-50 year old male who wants to maximize his muscle mass needs to induce adaptation through volume and mechanical load. This involves increasing the weight, the repetitions, or the number of sets. This will be uncomfortable and requires mental preparation. It is also important to build in tapers to actualize gains and recover. The taper cycle will get closer together the more advanced you get. After probably 4-8 weeks, a much bigger taper where we pull back on everything is recommended. The goal is to maximize hypertrophy and stimulus while minimizing fatigue.

title: Maximizing Hypertrophy While Minimizing Fatigue
content: It is possible to get a similar stimulus by going to failure and maybe even just a little bit more. But if it then causes you to have decreased performance the following week or not be able to push as hard overall, it is not beneficial. Training shy of failure a lot can still be beneficial. With compound movements specifically, you don’t have to get as close to failure to get the benefits. Stimulus for muscle growth occurs in the last 5 reps before failure. If you’re doing 20 reps, this means you need to get to at least 15 reps to get a similar stimulus.

title: Weight Lifting and Hypertrophy
content: If one likes lifting heavy weights but isn’t worried about creating strength, they can do 1 set under 5 reps and the rest at 6-10 reps for compound exercises. On isolation exercises, they can do 15-20 reps for variety. Research for short term gains (12 weeks) indicates there won't be a difference in hypertrophy between low reps up to 30 reps as long as the number of hard sets are equated. The sweet spot for hard sets is probably about 6 to 10 sets in a session (per body part). Improvements are not usually seen above 10 sets. If one rests longer, each set actually becomes more effective as a stimulus for hypertrophy, presumably because performance is better and more weight can be used and more reps can be done on that individual set.

title: Resistance Training Volume and Muscle Mass
content: If one is resting more than 3 minutes between sets, 6 sets (resting 1-2 minutes) might be more like 10 sets. It's not necessary to jump to 10 sets immediately per body part. It's recommended to use whatever is allowing one to adapt at the time. If one is relatively new to training, starting with 10 sets per body part could lead to a plateau and potentially outpace recovery capabilities. If one is squatting and deadlifting every day, they should be in very good physical condition to do that.

title: Maximizing Hypertrophy by Working a Muscle at a Long Muscle Length
content: It’s important to work a muscle at a long muscle length. Partial range of motion at lengthened muscle lengths produce similar hypertrophy as full range of motion. For example, a partial rep from straight to say 90 degrees is more effective than if you just do the top of the bicep, with the same range of motion. The bicep might be a little bit different because one would actually have to be on an incline bench to truly get the stretched range of motion.

title: Recommended Lower Body Exercise Routines and Training Frequency
content: For leg development, hack squats and pendulum squats are recommended. These exercises can really work through a nice full range of motion and create a lot of stimulus. It's usually good to have 2 main exercises for a big muscle group like that. For frequency, meta-analysis hasn’t been sensitive enough to pick it up. So far as we know, for legs, 1 time a week is enough and for upper-body, 2 times a week. Multiple times a week is probably beneficial for both.

title: Nutrition Plan for Muscle Gain
content: For a 40-50 year old male weighing 175-180 lbs and 20ish% body fat by DEXA, eating 120 g protein a day is a little light. It's recommended to have 200 grams a day. Also, calories and carb intake should be adequate for facilitating recovery. If one wants to gain lean mass, a slight caloric surplus is needed. An energy deficit impairs lean body mass accrual. From a mechanistic perspective, it activates AMP-kinase, which is an inhibitor of mTOR. From a teleological perspective, if there's no excess energy, muscle remodeling is extremely energy expensive.

title: Cycling Weight Gain and Weight Loss When Building Lean Muscle Mass
content: This man should eat a slight caloric surplus for about 8 weeks to gain 3 lbs of body weight. Since he’s been training for a long time and he’s older, the likelihood that he’s going to be able to gain lean mass without at least some body fat is probably pretty low. When one has been training for a long period of time, they have to have everything lined up just to gain ounces of lean body mass. Part of lining that up is a slight caloric surplus.

title: Weight Gain and Loss
content: Fat loss should be slow for people who are well trained. Weight gain should occur at a snail’s pace. As a rule of thumb, if you’re going to gain 5 lbs of total body weight, aim for 3 lb to be lean. This will probably take 12 weeks. But it might be more like 6 months. At 12 weeks you’re up to 5 lbs but then you work on reducing a bit of fat and come back down to a gain of only 3 lbs. This could be followed by another gaining cycle. With each cycle, the composition of lean tissue to fat gets a little bit better. When trained people put on weight it is often 50-50, lean mass to fat mass. Sometimes it’s 40-60, if you’re really well trained (40% lean, 60% fat).

title: Muscle Gain Limit
content: There is a limit to the amount of muscle that can be gained. The good thing is that when we lose body fat for resistance training, loss of body fat get a little better each cycle. Now, there are limits to this, your genetic limit. You never really know if you’re at your genetic limit. You never really hit a hard limit, rather the gains become some minimal it’s almost not measurable.

title: Resistance Training
content: Focus on making sure you can do a lot of resistance training. Because it’s going to take quite a big stimulus to get in there, focusing on stimulus versus fatigue. Do high stimulus, low fatigue movements so that you can accumulate enough volume without overreaching all the time. If you can train for 12 weeks without needing a taper versus six weeks, that’s more stimulus.

title: Caloric Surplus
content: Eat a slight caloric surplus, 200 calories a day over maintenance. This means there will be weeks where you don’t gain anything. Weight gain tends to come on in chunks. Just like weight loss occurs in chunks.

title: Protein Powder
content: Whey protein is high in leucine, branched amino acids [the ones that can be utilized by muscle], and essential amino acids. It generally tastes good and is well tolerated. Whey comes from cow’s milk. It’s a high-quality, easily digestible, very bioavailable source of protein. It’s top in terms of muscle protein synthesis; it always scores highest in research.

title: Branched-chain Amino Acids
content: Branched-chain amino acids are the only ones muscle can oxidize for energy, they are: leucine, isoleucine, and valine. If you’re getting enough total protein in, it doesn’t seem to be benefit to supplement with branched-chain amino acids. They may have a role in reducing muscle soreness.

title: Creatine
content: Creatine monohydrate used to be very popular. What you want to do is saturate your phosphocreatine stores in muscle cells. The benefits of creatine are boosting strength, hypertrophy, and recovery. It increases lean body mass, strength, and exercise performance. There may be cognitive benefits.

title: Nitrates and Nitric Oxide
content: Nitrates, nitrites do appear to enhance exercise performance. Beetroot juice and those sorts of things and sources of nitrites. A lot of supplements appear to not have in them what they say they have in them in terms of these nitrates.

title: Citrulline
content: Citrulline malate can be recycled into arginine and then into nitric oxide. So citrulline malate or citrulline specifically, actually increases blood nitrate levels more than arginine itself. If you’re looking at citrulline specifically, take 6-8 g per dose. Citrulline is taken more to increase performance than hypertrophy.

title: Timing of Supplements
content: Pre-workout— citrulline. Post-workout— whey protein. When should creatine be taken? The timing doesn’t seem to be important. Thinking about the mechanism, it shouldn’t matter because it’s a long term thing.

title: Intra-workout Nutrition
content: Not particularly emphasizing on intra-workout nutrition, unless the workouts are really long or there are multiple sessions per day.
